subject: Re: [junit] Chris' excellent test-splitting adventure
msgSnippet: ... [snippety-snip] ... I don t think we can change to subversion; too many users (potential or real) would have to change as well. (I don t know if we can
messageBody:
On Tuesday 07 June 2005 16:29, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> Chris Dollin wrote:

[snippety-snip]

> > What do you do that if I did it too I could do better? Apart from using
> > a faster CVS server, that is.
>
> Well...
>
> 1. I use Subversion, so I don't have the same CVS issues you seem to
> have. It also looks like you have far too much stuff in a single CVS
> server or module. It looks like it's time to split them.

I don't think we can change to subversion; too many users (potential
or real) would have to change as well. (I don't know if we can mirror
a CVS with a subversion or vice-versa. A year or so ago I did try and
find if there was a CVS mirror application, so that we could use a
local CVS server for development and refresh the remote CVS asynchronously,
but my Google-fu was low.)

For similar (user-oriented) reasons, I don't *think* we could split
the codebase into multiple modules.

On good days, the CVS is acceptably fast. It's just that the bad days
happen when you need speed. At least it seems that way.

> 2. It looks like you're spending a great deal of your effort maintaining
> test suites. I suppose you have to do that for some good reason, but
> when I run my tests, I run them all. If I need two categories of tests,
> that's two source trees. (test/source and slowtest/source)

Perhaps I didn't paint a correct picture. The only suite maintenance
we usually do is that the tests for package X.P, which live in X.P.test,
are collected into a suite (usually, and I think suboptimally, named
TestPackage); and X.test has a suite that includes X.P.test.TestPackage,
etc upwards.

So when a new test [suite] materialises, there's a one-line edit in
the appropriate TestPackage.

[The DB tests are a separate subsuite, but share code because of
abstract test cases.]

> 3. How often do you want to run only a subset of tests that isn't, for
> example, a coherent package of tests?

Hardly ever. Just sometimes, I'd like to assemble a nonce suite of
"that one there, this one here"; it's never been enough of a problem
to force a solution.

> In Eclipse, I mostly right-click
> either the source tree or the package and run the tests.

Yes. (Actually, mostly it's left-click the Run button.)

> 4. For the "helper code", I generally make that stuff class-level as
> preparation for the refactoring, so it doesn't get in my way while I'm
> moving tests around. I spend less time in limbo with compile errors or
> red tests.

That's a possibility. I'll bear that in mind for the next time; of course,
it does add another step, but the payback might be worth it.

> 5. Yes, I would imagine you have too many global caches. :)

I'm not sure if it's one or two ...

Actually, the nasty dependency problem is bnodes - "blank nodes" in
RDF - which have nonce IDs based on UIDs. Which means they're different
each run. Which means they hash differently ditto. Which means things
come out of tables in different orders. Which means that order-dependent
buggy code can appear to work ...

... which means that we all know that if that appears to be happening
(ie tests will pass, then fail, with no code changes) we lock down the
bnode ID generation.

> 6. I'm not sure why renaming a recently-created class is such a pain,
> even in CVS: it hardly has any history to worry about, so I wouldn't
> worry about it.

It's just the Historical Broken Record; experience shows that I'm likely
to make a mistake when doing it.

> How long does this whole dance actually take for you? I imagine it's
> more than one minute.

I'd call it five. Not flowy.

[I just did a CVS update; `time` reports that it took 1m11.938s, ie,
significantly over a minute. No updates arrived.]

--
Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
It's called *extreme* programming, not *stupid* programming.
